#Text=Tom Bayer
#Text=For the German writer and musician , see Thommie Bayer .
#Text=Thomas Montgomery Bayer is a Vanuatuan banker .
#Text=A former U.S. citizen , he served in the Vietnam War and thereafter remained in the Asia-Pacific region to pursue a career in the finance sector .
#Text=He lived successively in Australia and Singapore before coming to Vanuatu ( then the New Hebrides ) in 1974 , where he became a citizen after independence , and has continued to reside there .
#Text=Previously executive chairman of European Bank and managing director of the Pacific International Trust Company , he is now a member of the board of directors of the Reserve Bank of Vanuatu .
#Text=Early career
#Text=A native of Pennsylvania , Bayer graduated from Lehigh University before going on to the Wharton School of Business . [ 1 ] [ 2 ]
#Text=He served in the United States Army during the Vietnam War , attaining the rank of captain . [ 3 ]
#Text=After leaving the U.S. military , Bayer worked in international banking .
#Text=He moved to Australia in 1967 , and later to Singapore . [ 4 ]

#Text=He moved from Singapore to the New Hebrides in 1974 to become the vice-managing director of the Pacific International Trust Company , and was promoted to managing director the following year . [ 5 ]
#Text=His relocation came just as the groundwork was being laid for the islands ' independence from the United Kingdom and France ; [ 3 ]
#Text=when Vanuatu became independent in 1980 and asked prominent members of society to take Vanuatu citizenship , Bayer chose to accept in 1982 , giving up U.S. citizenship in the process . [ 4 ]
#Text=European Bank
#Text=Bayer became the executive chairman of European Bank in 1986 . [ 6 ]
#Text=The bank began expanding its business in the mid-1990s . [ 4 ]

#Text=European Bank faced investigations by foreign regulatory authorities in July 1999 when one of its account-holders deposited US$ 7.5 million in funds which U.S. officials believed to be the proceeds of a credit card fraud . [ 7 ] [ 8 ]

#Text=This was part of a larger wave of concern about financial institutions in the South Pacific which led a number of U.S. banks , including the Bank of New York and JP Morgan Chase , to suspend dollar transactions not just with Vanuatu but Nauru and Palau and eventually Niue as well . [ 9 ]

#Text=Bayer was critical of this response , noting that Vanuatu had criminalised money laundering as early as 1989 , and voiced his suspicions that both the U.S. government and U.S. banks were insincere in their desire to crack down on money laundering , but rather had turned their attention to Vanuatu because it was a small and distant target , and one of the few offshore financial centres which was not a dependency of major foreign powers . [ 10 ] [ 11 ]

#Text=Nevertheless , Vanuatu also pursued a diplomatic approach to resolving the situation , in which Bayer played a large role : a Vanuatu delegation headed by Bayer went to the U.S. and met with International Monetary Fund , U.S. State Department , and Federal Reserve System officials in January 2000 to discuss details of Vanuatu 's anti-money laundering laws and practices , and arranged for reciprocal visits by State Department and Financial Action Task Force officials to Port Vila in the following months .
#Text=This was successful in persuading some banks to resume transactions with Vanuatu , but other correspondent banks in the U.S. continued to apply sanctions . [ 10 ]

#Text=Furthermore , in May 2002 the U.S. indicted Bayer and two colleagues on charges including laundering the proceeds of another business through European Bank , and again had the bank 's funds in the U.S. frozen .

#Text=Bayer was confident that the charges would be thrown out , stating in January 2003 that the charge of money laundering was being applied to actions that were nothing more than " normal banking business " . [ 12 ] [ 13 ] [ 14 ]

column1: #Text=In March 2012 , after nearly a decade of litigation , European Bank successfully unfroze its accounts and had its funds returned , with interest . [ 15 ] [ 16 ]
#Text=Reserve Bank of Vanuatu
#Text=Bayer retired from his position as PITCO chairman in November 2011 . [ 5 ]
#Text=In June 2012 , then-Minister of Finance Moana Carcasses appointed Bayer to the board of the Reserve Bank of Vanuatu . [ 15 ]

#Text=Opposition politicians including Serge Vohor of the Union of Moderate Parties , Jeff Patunvanu of Nagriamel , and members of the Vanua'aku Pati questioned the move due to Bayer 's previous association with European Bank . [ 17 ]

#Text=In March 2013 , new Minister of Finance Charlot Salawai , who succeeded to the position after Carcasses lost his seat in the October 2012 elections , attempted to remove Bayer from the RBV board , claiming that he was an agent of European Bank and was thus disqualified from serving under the Reserve Bank of Vanuatu Act Section 8(10)(b ) . [ 18 ] [ 19 ]

#Text=Bayer described the dismissal as illegal and Salawai 's claim as misleading and defamatory as he had not been a board member of European Bank for more than a decade , and suggested that the move was tied to party politics . [ 20 ]

#Text=The following month , after the collapse of the Sato Kilman government in whose cabinet Salawai served , and the election of Carcasses ( who had since crossed the floor ) as Prime Minister , RBV Governor Odo Tevi himself was removed after more than ten years in his position .
#Text=Members of Parliament expressed differing opinions on the issue :
#Text=Robert Bohn Sikol stated that " Tevi had done a good job and was not sacked " , whereas Leader of the Opposition Ham Lini described it as retaliation for Bayer 's removal . [ 21 ]
#Text=In August 2013 , Bayer was again appointed to the RBV board by new Minister of Finance Maki Simelum . [ 22 ]
#Text=Footnotes
